Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2008 05:15PM hi5 wrote: Hi everyone: I too had close margins.  Even though I had a mastectomy I had to have rads with bolus because tumour was too close to muscle. What a bummer!!! I'd had bilat with reconstruction and didn't expect to have to have rads.  Because of deep incisions and probably the rads my bc boob does not look that great e even reconstructed...has a creasing affect.  Anyone else out there had the same. Also I was borderline for needing chemo...onc sent specimen back for 2nd report but because I was borderline he decided I didn't need chemo.  Go figure.

Posts.Title: Symptroms of lymphadema? LizM CherylG

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2007 06:02PM hi5 wrote: I am the third of 4 sis to have bc.  The first sis passed away at 33.( My daughter and I went to a genetics counsellor to see if we could be ( prior to my dx,,,2nd sis refused  have genetic testing,,,,were told that they wanted a bc survivor so we couldn't get it done.)  After I was dx'ed the other sis did have the testing done...she tested positive for the brca 1 gene. After all her daughters, my daughter and the deceased sis' daughters have been tested and all have the gene.  This has allowed everyone to become proactive in their preventative measures. I think it is a good thing to have genetic testing done. I had an oopheroctomy and hysterectomy in Sept. and am glad I chose to have a bilateral mastectomy when I was dx'ed with IDC.  My daughter had an oophm hyster and cervix removed in November, my twin nieces (29 years old) had prophylactic bilateral mastectomies, their sis will have hers in January and the deceased sis' twins are having their consult in the near future. I was aware of the 50% chance but we are definitely batting 100%!!!
Posts.Title: Question on BRACA1 Gene??? Cherlilly leaf

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2007 03:13AM hi5 wrote: I completed rads end of August 2006 and still have the "rad tan".... I had a bolus so this whole side is well tanned.  I also had no problems with blistering etc. and I used the suggested creams BUT a few weeks after completion of rads the blistering etc started and last close to a month.  I also have hypothyroid now.
Posts.Title: breast still swollen - two years post radiation melmedic06 Binney4

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2007 02:40AM hi5 wrote: I am the third of 4 sis to get bc...the first passed away at 33.  The second got the testing done after I was dx'ed (  at the time we found out she had bc the genetic counsellors wouldn't do a test on me..wanted a survivor)...anyways she probably saved a lot of lives since having the genetic testing done. We have the brca1 gene and so do all our daughters and the sister who passed away her daughters have it too.  so far I have had ooph and hyster and so has my daughter. My nieces have had prophylactic masts etc etc.  I am sure many more bc would have shown up so I am grateful for the test.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2007 03:13AM hi5 wrote: zar:   I want you to know that I am beside you all the way.  I can't imagine what you are going through but the thought of all the unknowns is a very frightful one.  But, I agree with C...you are much stronger than you think you are.  You are a fighter that's why you're still with us...I remember your fears when you first felt the lumps on your clavicle and all the bs the different docs were giving you.  You persevered and that was 10 months ago...you have done so much in the past ten months ...travel, concerts etc. and you have so much more to do in the next ten months and the ten months after that and on and on. Take care Lots of hugs and loves to you

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2008 02:51AM hi5 wrote: I am the third of 4 sisters to get bc.  The first one passed on at 33 leaving behind 3 daughters. Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2007 02:57PM hi5-2006Aug13 wrote: cass: I tested postive for the brca gene and will be having an ooph and hyster in September. ( I was dx'ed with bc in May 2006 and had bilateral mast.) My daughter was also tested and has the gene as well. The clinician at the hereditary clinic said that if the mother does NOT have the gene she cannot pass it down to her children and if she has the gene there is a 50-50 chance of children getting it.
